comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: This is in fact the Gare du Nord (see the name of the hotel "Terminus Nord" and compare the Wikipedia pictures, the Gare de l'Est – note spelling – looks significantly different). The Gare du Nord connects Paris with Brussels, the Gare de l'Est Paris and Strasbourg, and today all the way to Berlin or Munich... PS It looks like the caption on the photograph, even though it is partly obscured, correctly puts this near the Gare du Nord.

comment.author: 92284803@N00
comment._content: Belgian reservists apparently not fond of the Boater so predominate in the rest of the Bain Collection, instead have chosen to wear Fisherman's Caps.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: trialsanderrors: Thank you for correctly identifying this train station as the Gare du Nord. We will fix the title to reflect what is written on the negative when we update the database.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: On Agence Meurisse photo at Gallica site (probably where Bain got this), caption is "Belges ne pouvant s'embarquer à la gare du Nord (Belgians not allowed to embark at Gare du Nord [?]) So perhaps these are not reservists, but Belgians trying to return to their families from Paris during the German invasion? gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b9041325k/f1

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: artolog: thanks for another matching image from Gallica. We will add the additional title and Agence Meurisse to  the image description when we update. It would be interesting to know more context about why the Belgians could not embark at this station.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: I'd also like to know why they all have those striped kit bags and curvy canes.  There was so much going on in August, 1914 that it might be tough to find this story.
